descript.abstract: International Airports is a point theme representing over 1,000 airports worldwide. Attribute information includes the airport name and the name of the closest city.
descript.purpose: For educational, non-commercial purposes. This dataset is appropriate for use in a GIS.
descript.supplinf: Air transport is playing an increasing role in global and intercontinental freight, mail, and passenger traffic. It is characterized by high speeds and the ability to overcome natural obstacles. It is one of the most important kinds of passenger transport today, especially for distances greater than 1,000 kilometers. Air transportation leads in continental and intercontinental international passenger traffic. In the 1990s the passenger volume of air transport exceeded 200 billion passenger kilometers. Airports are the key element in the air transport system and transport infrastructure. There are several tens of thousands of airports in the world. Among them, international airports are of great importance.

citeinfo.title: Timetables of 1994: Aeroflot, Aerolineas Argentinas, Air France, Air India, Alitalia, ANA, Austrian AUA, Aviaco, Binter, British Airways, Delta Airlines, Deutsche BA, Finnair, Iberia, JAL, KLM, Ladeco, LOT, Lufthansa, Malev, SAS, Swissair, Turkish Airlines, Viasa, Viva Air.

procstep.procdesc: International airports were identified as those airports with direct international flights. The basic network was determined using world atlases and revised by a great number of cartographic and reference materials including flight timetables of air companies and ICAO (International Civil Aviation Organization) reference books. Guidebooks, tourist maps, city plans and maps, a few local newspapers, and other materials were also used if the timetables were not enough to identify and select airports. Timetables of air companies in some African countries, Indonesia, Brazil, Oceania, and some other countries were supplemented in particular. The location of airports relative to cities was identified by the timetables, which typically include such information. Then the information was revised by city maps and plans and passenger traffic charts. In some cases, only geographical direction from cities is shown for airports (mostly in the countries of the former USSR). ICAO codes are quoted for most airports excluding comparatively small airports of some regions including the former USSR.

procstep.procdesc: Datasets for each continent were converted from ESRI coverage to the ESRI shapefile format using the 'copy features' tool and merged into one layer using the 'merge' tool.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: The name of the city nearest to an airport
Codes for any diacritical marks in the name
A local or previous name for a city
Contains a two-letter country code for the country in which an airport is located
The distance from the airport to the nearest city, in kilometers
